property.name: text
property.value:
Simulate a ball dropping towards a rotating disc. The disc has doors bored into opposite ends that will allow the particle to "tunnel" through if the disc is properly aligned at the time of impact.
Ball drops are detected by a photosensor, which reports the time at which the particle was detected, as well as its initial velocity. The controller adjusts the position of the disc to ensure the door is directly below the particle at the time of impact.
Following the initial ball drop, the next ball will drop after a fixed delay. Between ball drops, the disc should return to its default speed.
All units used in this model are SI (meters, seconds), except for rotation which is in units of encoder units, parameterized by encoderTicksPerRevolution.

property.name: text
property.value:
When triggered, generate two photo pulses that correspond to the physical times a ball passes through two photodetectors separated by a fixed distance.
Introduce a random delay between photo events, which will randomize the initial velocity of the ball in motion.

entity.name: Gaussian
entity.doc: Create a sequence of gaussian random variables

property.name: text
property.value:
When a ball is detected (an event is present on the photoPulse port), record the initial time and velocity of the ball and determine when it will impact the disc. These values are stored in registers and used as controller parameters.
When disc state changes, the servo decoder receives an encoder pulse. These events are frequent and pseudo-periodic, and are the driving signal of the controller. If a ball impact is pending, the planner will plot a trajectory for the disc such that the door is aligned below the ball at the time of impact. A PID controller then drives the disc to track this trajectory. If no ball impact is pending, the trajectory follows a constant default rate.
It is important to note that the encoder pulse frequency directly sets the controller rate. If a high- precision controller is used (more ticks per rotation), or the default disc rate is high, then the controller will operate at a higher frequency.

property.name: text
property.value:
Convert the servo encoder signal into the disc rate and angle. Each tick event corresponds to a fractional degree of rotation; the time delay between these ticks is inversely proportional to the rate.
The value of the encoder tick reflects the number of ticks recorded for a single encoder event; this value should be 1, though values of 0 can force controller output without affecting disc state.
TODO: Upon receiving an alignment event, the accumulator needs to adjust to the nearest complete rotation. This accounts for any drift between the actual disc position and the accumulated value.

property.name: text
property.value: Receive particle sensor pulses; the time difference between the two events corresponds to the initial velocity of the particle in motion. The second event occurs when the particle is a fixed altitude from the disc.

property.name: text
property.value:
Simple kinematics model for a dropping ball. Given initial altitude, initial velocity, and the time at which these values were valid (t0), calculate the final velocity and time of impact (with respect to global time).
impactTime = (sqrt(initialVelocity^2 + 2*g*initialAltitude) - initialVelocity) / g impactVelocity = initialVelocity + g*impactTime

property.name: text
property.value:
If a ball impact is pending, then plan a trajectory for the disc such that the door is aligned below the ball at the time of impact.
If no impact is pending, then drive the disc at a default rate.

property.name: text
property.value: Plan desired rate, then multiply by the previous time gap to estimate the position when this actor next fires.

property.name: text
property.value:
If timeToImapct > 0, then a particle impact is imminent, and the desired rate is chosen such that the door is aligned at the time of impact.
If timeToImapct <= 0, then output the fixed default rate.

entity.name: PID
entity.doc: Discrete proportional, integral, and derivative controller.
